subject: QuickScript in Unicode
msgSnippet: Hi All... long time lurker first time poster. In playing with quickscript and looking at the various fonts available, the mapping of QS onto the existing Latin
messageBody:
Hi All... long time lurker first time poster.

In playing with quickscript and looking at the various fonts available, the mapping of
QS onto the existing Latin character range has seemed to be a problem. I think we
should try to get quickscript into the Unicode standard. (Please forgive me if this is
already in-progress, but I couldn't find any information suggesting that on the net.)

While I think that "Read Alphabet" is a much better name, it is a drawback when trying
to do Google searches. Therefore I have decided upon Quickscript as it is spelled
most often in the QS manual.

I have uploaded an image file in the "Resources" directory which I mean to serve as an
initial letter count. It has several differences to any of the font implementations I
have seen, notably:
* includes 'full height' angled and squared brackets
* includes a 'full height' slash character
* includes the four alternate 'forward baseline' characters (they, may, no, utter)
* includes the six half letters (pea, tea, he, way, day, zoo) without 'steps' or zig-zags
* includes two 'step' characters on the top or baseline
* includes a 'guide' character, indicating the position of the top/baseline
(this looks a bit like a colon, to be used as a writing guide when creating forms etc.)
* does NOT include any ligatures (yew, air, are, or, -er)

In total, this amounts to 62 characters, and could be encoded into a 64-character
space on the Unicode table. Numbers, punctuation, and other existing symbols
would of course be included in Quickscript fonts; but they would be placed at their
normal (i. e. Latin) positions. The Shavian Unicode implementation does this even for
the namer dot, though I think the mid-dot looks sufficiently different to warrant its
inclusion.

Please take a look and let me know if you think I've missed any. What follows is a list
of the proposed names, also included in the image file.

oliver


LETTER PEA
LETTER BAY
LETTER TEA
LETTER DAY
LETTER KEY
LETTER GAY
LETTER THEW
LETTER THEY
LETTER FEE
LETTER VIE
LETTER SEE
LETTER ZOO
LETTER SHE
LETTER J-AI
LETTER CHEER
LETTER JAY
LETTER YE
LETTER WAY
LETTER HE
LETTER WHY
LETTER ING
LETTER MAY
LETTER NO
LETTER LOW
LETTER ROE
LETTER LOCH
LETTER LLAN
LETTER EXCITE
LETTER EXAMINE
LETTER IT
LETTER EAT
LETTER ET
LETTER EIGHT
LETTER AT
LETTER I
LETTER AH
LETTER AME
LETTER OX
LETTER OY
LETTER UTTER
LETTER OUT
LETTER OME
LETTER FOOT
LETTER OOZE
LETTER THEY BASELINE
LETTER MAY BASELINE
LETTER NO BASELINE
LETTER UTTER BASELINE
LETTER PEA HALF
LETTER TEA HALF
LETTER HE HALF
LETTER WAY HALF
LETTER DAY HALF
LETTER ZOO HALF
LETTER TOP STEP
BOTTOM STEP
NAMER DOT
LEFT ANGLE BRACKET
RIGHT ANGLE BRACKET
LEFT SQUARE BRACKET
RIGHT SQUARE BRACKET
GUIDE

Hi All... long time lurker first time poster.

In playing with quickscript and looking at the various fonts available, the mapping of 
QS onto the existing Latin character range has seemed to be a problem.  I think we 
should try to get quickscript into the Unicode standard.  (Please forgive me if this is 
already in-progress, but I couldn't find any information suggesting that on the net.)

While I think that "Read Alphabet" is a much better name, it is a drawback when trying 
to do Google searches.  Therefore I have decided upon Quickscript as it is spelled 
most often in the QS manual.

I have uploaded an image file in the "Resources" directory which I mean to serve as an 
initial letter count.  It has several differences to any of the font implementations I 
have seen, notably:
* includes 'full height' angled and squared brackets
* includes a 'full height' slash character
* includes the four alternate 'forward baseline' characters (they, may, no, utter)
* includes the six half letters (pea, tea, he, way, day, zoo) without 'steps' or zig-zags
* includes two 'step' characters on the top or baseline
* includes a 'guide' character, indicating the position of the top/baseline
   (this looks a bit like a colon, to be used as a writing guide when creating forms etc.)
* does NOT include any ligatures (yew, air, are, or, -er)

In total, this amounts to 62 characters, and could be encoded into a 64-character 
space on the Unicode table.  Numbers, punctuation, and other existing symbols 
would of course be included in Quickscript fonts; but they would be placed at their 
normal (i. e. Latin) positions.  The Shavian Unicode implementation does this even for 
the namer dot, though I think the mid-dot looks sufficiently different to warrant its 
inclusion.

Please take a look and let me know if you think I've missed any.  What follows is a list 
of the proposed names, also included in the image file.

oliver
